>>18774162
Both. Give it a shot. I keep them in jar with one way valves, "burp" for the first week, then don't open them until I sample or feel like freezing. You wouldn't believe the gas that still comes off my pourovers after a month rest+a month frozen. Lighter roasts rest for way longer. Moodtrap(ultra light roaster) used to explicitly say 45+ day rest on their bags.
https://espressoaf.com/guides/storage.html

>>18772909
>Why does this legit have to make the best tasting cup of coffee for me? Is it more forgiving then other methods?
Water boils at lower temperatures the lower the air pressure, with it boiling at something stupidly low, like 12° C in a total vacuum. That's also why baking and cooking instructions also had different temperatures for higher altitudes. With a consumer coffee siphon, the water will boil at something like 93° C or lower, resulting in a better cup of coffee because you don't extract the more bitter compounds in the grounds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The real scientific hangover cure is:

Water, can include electrolyte sachet
Eat a whole raw yellow grapefruit or drink half a litre of no added sugar grapefruit juice slowly(Not pink grapefruit)
A slice of toast with peanut butter
Wait a short while and drink a strong coffee
10mins of exercise

Theory is; Water to rehydrate, Yellow grapefruit contains lots of amino acids that your liver uses to remove alcohol from your bloodstream. Toast has slow burning energy to fuel the process and peanut butter contains lots of Iron that your liver and kidneys need to replenish for optimal function. Once your liver is loaded with amino acids, down a strong coffee to increase bloodflow, exercise to increase your heart rate to cycle the blood through your liver while the Amino acids are working.
US Military used this for a long time as the beginning of their 3day diet for people who got fat during breaks between deployment.

>traditional
the prairie oyster is indeed a classic hangover cure and tastes bretty gud. their recipe needs some work, though:
>egg yolk
>2 dashes each salt, pepper, tabasco, worcestershire sauce
>pinch of horseradish
it's been around since the 1800s.

>hedonistic
this is a cocktail called the suffering bastard and was invented in WWII for hungover troops by a bartender at a famous hotel in egypt.

>scientific
it's objectively true that a proper electrolyte powder dissolved in water is probably the best thing you can drink to help get over a hangover.

Wow. I have never seen a more homosexual image in all my life.

Personally I tried hair of the dog but that's just asking for alcoholism. It doesn't actually work.

A classic technique is just taking some headache pills before you start getting a headache (when you feel your head tightening a bit, now is the time). Then drinking water as you go, maybe have a slice of toast before bed, all these together helps prevent a bad hangover in the first place.
If you're drinking heavily, avoid any strong painkillers, it's a bad combo and can leave you struggling to breathe. Best to just skip it in this case. Wake up and force a good breakfast in you, something with lots of carbs works well.
It may feel like shit but nothing is worse than lying in bed with a hangover and just suffering.
I avoid dairy the morning after because my stomach does not thank me after lots of drinking. Stay hydrated, eat something salty and filling before bed and you're practically good to go.

>>18776549
Sorry, I get it now. If you're talking about home cooking, the basic domestic Canadian staple aside from the obvious Kraft Dinner is scrumpy wumpy. You Americans sometimes get factory-made scrumpy, but the real thing is much simpler: you just take a slice of white bread, spread a 50/50 mixture of ketchup and margarine, roll the bread into a tube, and tie it up with edible culinary twine. After that, you can bake it, or fry it, or even grill it, although breakfast scrumpy is usually eaten cold/raw. For lunch and supper, it's dipped in the hot cheesy Kraft Dinner. For tea, sometimes you add jam, but using too much jam is considered a "hoser" (low-class) stereotype, avoided by most civilised people. In Quebec, scrumpy wumpy is usually available as a side dish as poutine shops; some french purists discourage it, but it's a natural companion to the leftover horse gravy. At the daily hockey matches during Canadian winter (September-April), you can also buy cold scrumpy on stick that's been freezing in the snow. What a treat! That's one of the main things that Canuck expats miss when traveling abroad. Because sure, you can often find store-bought scrumpy wumpy in areas with many Canadian immigrants, but the manufacturers usually get it wrong somehow, like using butter instead of margarine, or using the wrong kind of jam. (Proper scrumpy jam comes ONLY from the Faggleberry bush in the Northern Territories; it practically supports their whole economy.)

I hoped this helped, and please do consider supporting Canadian tourism! Haldo! (That means, "Greetings to you!" in Canadian.)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18774705
>Because its a chicken burger.... as opposed to a beef burger
Maybe this is a culture difference between America and Europe? When you say chicken burger I think a beef burger that got topped with chicken (You can get this some places. The chicken is usually fried chicken strips cut into pieces). Usually "something" burger just means a burger with a lot of "something" in or on it, but it still has beef. Onion burger is a good example. It has a lot of onions mixed in with the meat and also on top of the meat.

The only real exception is veggie burger, but even then some people will assume you mean a burger with a lot of vegetables on it instead of one that has a vegetable patty. Places that sell both usually call one Veggie Burger and the other Garden Burger to have a difference for making orders.

That random food box looks nice. Thank you for telling me. If I ever have to go in England I will look for that.

For the botanical usage, see Berry (botany). For other uses, see Berry (disambiguation).

A berry is a small, pulpy, and often edible fruit. Typically, berries are juicy, rounded, brightly colored, sweet, sour or tart, and do not have a stone or pit, although many pips or seeds may be present.[1] Common examples are strawberries, raspberries, blueberries, blackberries, red currants, white currants and blackcurrants.[2] In Britain, soft fruit is a horticultural term for such fruits.[3][4][5]

Japanese barberries

Japanese barberries
Bilberry

Red currants

Red currants
Honeysuckle

Honeysuckle
Gooseberries

Gooseberries
Cloudberry

Cloudberry
Highbush blueberries

Highbush blueberries
Blackberries

Blackberries

In common usage, the term "berry" differs from the scientific or botanical definition of a fruit produced from the ovary of a single flower in which the outer layer of the ovary wall develops into an edible fleshy portion (pericarp). The botanical definition includes many fruits that are not commonly known or referred to as berries, such as grapes, tomatoes, cucumbers, eggplants, bananas, and chili peppers. Fruits commonly considered berries but excluded by the botanical definition include strawberries, raspberries, and blackberries, which are aggregate fruits and mulberries, which are multiple fruits. Watermelons and pumpkins are giant berries that fall into the category "pepos". A plant bearing berries is said to be bacciferous or baccate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18773256
the pepsi challenge will almost always be won by pepsi, unless you take a 10-15 min break between tasting the two in order to allow your taste buds to reset. This is because pepsi is sweeter, so coke tastes less sweet or even bitter by comparison.
scenario 1: taste pepsi then coke => pepsi tastes sweet, coke tastes bitter, pepsi wins.
scenario 2: taste coke then pepsi => coke tastes sweet, pepsi also tastes sweet, either can win.
so the extra sweetness of pepsi essentially tilts the board in its favor if the two are tasted one right after the other - you can expect pepsi to win ~75% of the time. but tasted in isolation, most people prefer coca cola because for most people - even most burgers - pepsi is just too sweet.

The pepsi challenge led coca cola to introduce "new coke" in the 80's, it was coca cola with more sweetness of pepsi, specifically formulated to beat pepsi on the pepsi challenge. coca cola's market testing of this new coke was exclusively done via a pepsi challenge style study, and found it to be a great success, unfortunately they didn't bother with traditional market testing. consumers rejected new coke in droves, forcing coca cola to introduce a lower-sweetness version of coke that was more comparable to the old coca cola.

>>18776028
I'm not sure what aspect is tripping you up but I'd say work on the stock. Starting with a high quality stock is 90% of the work. Make sure you use meat not just bones, this part is important.
Then you can reduce the stock and freeze it. That way when you put some in the pan to make your sauce it's already at the right consistency and everything is easy.

>Make sure you use meat not just bones
Seriously fuck those plebs, who shill those bone water swills instead of proper fonds which will have some actual flavour. Also don't roast the shit out of everything. Roasting the meat, bones and vegetables slightly will be enough as the brown colour will come by alone and won't result in off flavours. Dark amber coloured fond should be the goal not something that looks like you added a ton of caramel colouring to it.
Also don't go to heavy on the vegetables. Rather make a vegetable fond on it's own.

>>18774619
Say what you will about Alton Brown's media personality, but he's lookin' on fleek these days, kinda like Walter White from Breaking Bad in an alternate universe where meth got legalized and he made legit billions.

I do kinda miss his old TV persona though, the "fun high school teacher" with slightly unkempt hair, Hawai'ian shirts, and an affably goofy smile, perfect for a 1990s cooking program when Food Network was just beginning to experiment with the intersection between food and entertainment, and trying to attract new demographics. Alton Brown earned his place in that era of TV history. The "internet science commentator" meme is kinda played out in 2023, but in 1999 the "popular food science" angle was honestly pretty cool and attracted numerous young men to try educational food "experiments" leading to lifelong skills. Plus some of the "tools" were fun. (Notably: using a blowdryer to turbocharge a charcoal grill, I had never heard of that before.)

So that's all neat and I hope Alton Brown is doing better these days. Thanks for reading my blog.

>>18763936
tater tot "hotdish" (casserole).

it's basically browned ground beef mixed with cream of mushroom soup, corn (optional), green beans (optional), put into a casserole dish with a layer of cheese and tater tots on top. basically it's something you could make when you live somewhere cold and remote where it's winter most of the year, and the only things you can get fresh are beef and dairy. a cuisine based around canned or frozen goods.

it's better than it looks if the tater tots and beef are good. I prefer it without the corn and green beans, though I like vegetables, because the canned veggie flavor permeates the dish. natives prefer it that way apparently.

checked. I think the word "hotdish" is just a midwestern thing, and only Minnesota and North Dakota afaik. but hotdish/casserole culture definitely seems to be a bigger deal here than anywhere else I've lived. it seems like the culture around it goes back to WWI and depression era times of scarcity, when canned foods were novel and popular, and of course because it's cheap and easy to make for potlucks and gatherings (e.g. for church). I'm not from this region originally but it's all interesting to me, and a good casserole is pretty nice. certain other regions in the US I've lived in don't seem to have such distinct regional cuisines.

I want to make a casserole now. we just got like a foot of snow last night and the power was out. any comfy recommendations?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Aus/fag/ here.
It's a misconception to say that there's "Australian food",our county is only 300 years old.

Instead there's three largely separate things going on in Austrian cuisine.
>indigenous products/ "bush tucker"
A range of interesting primary products, many of which weren't actually eaten by indigenous people, most suck are are eaten mainly by self hating European urbanites; but some like Tasmanian wild pepper, the fajoa have culinary merit
>rural cooking
Traditional cooking tied to primary production, often linked to settler colonialism. What does a farmer do with a metric ton of moth eaten apples? Can you eat the green part of an onion?
>modern Australian
Food cooked by chefs who could live anywhere, for restaurants that want global acclaim, patronized by tourists and the rich.

There's very little crossover.
In one corner there's a shaved sunburnt orangutans sitting on the floor eating a bowl of sour fruit.
In the other corner is a farmer baking apple pie.
In the other corner is a Japanese guy smoking salmon with Tasmanian inspired wasabi.
If Australian cuisine was to have a fourth corner, it would be an orgy of fast food mascots in an oil bath

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18759863
It really varies from region to region (there actually are 'local things' you just need to travel a bit and actively look out to notice them) and due to our being a colonial nation it's largely heterogenous - so British, Chinese, Vietnamese, Indian food all play a part.

Things that are distinctively Australian would be suburban staples that make use of produce that has always been abundant and popular - things like meat hand pies, sausage rolls, beef sausages, rissoles and lamb grilled over a simple gas barbeque, fresh fruit and veg, prawns, etc. Then there are things we've taken and modified from abroad (think British curry - but we've mostly nicked and bastardised things from Greeks/Italians) like Australian chicken parm, spag bol, banh mi, sausage curry, etc. Finally there are things that are mostly or entirely unique and based on native produce or conditions exclusive to Australia and its development (and are also often kind of fucked up) like vegemite scrolls, pavlova, lamingtons, damper, kangaroo sausages, mince and steaks, wallaby, crocodile, barramundi, macadamia nuts, finger limes, eucalyptus and lemon myrtle, etc.

The things we do really well that you can find elsewhere are also frequently world class. Think big stinky red wines, cheese, beef, lamb, sugar, oysters, abalone, crayfish and wheat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18763939
We do have a fair number of diners around here with roots in the mid-twentieth century but it's hard to find one with small-town charm. Highway diners are often glorified family restaurants and/or truck stops, urban diners are overpriced refuges for drunks after last call, and the New England Greek diners have mostly lost what made them Greek in the best sense. My favorite diner memory is from little place with a forgotten name in a forgotten town on a smaller throughway in upper-state New York. The tuna melt sandwich was solid home cooking, and the hostess/waitress might as well have been your aunt. 100-to-1 it was a family business that is now gone, but it would be fun to try and find it again. We talk a lot of shit about boomers, but they kept a lot of those old joints alive. Fetishized "retro" theme restaurants are usually fake and/or gay (though I do appreciate the decreased likelihood of being keelhauled under a pickup truck by locals who don't like my haircut.)

>>18773564
For any dish requiring eggplants, from baba to curries to pasta sauce, you can superdupersize them by doing the following prep (if you have a grill or gas burner): after a quick wash, but without skinning or soaking, put them over a low open flame for about an hour (maybe 40 minutes is fine, but no less than 30), turning every once in a while. The skin should fall right off when you're done, leaving a mash of eggplant with (if you've cooked it long enough) no bitterness. Remove the seedy part if it's over-ripe or still a bit bitter.

The fire-roast is *essential* to perfect homemade baba -- you can make it with unhomogenized peanut butter or whatever for nuttiness and oiliness instead of tahini (anything from coconut puree to, I dunno), but just using the grilled eggplant and some seasoning will carry the dish 99% of the way. Be aware there might be a shitload of tannins and umami, so you may have to tone it down or dilute it a bit if you're also using wine, meat, oily fish, etc. I don't think you can overdo roasting veggies really with the skin on, but you can definitely underdo it with the standard big bitter Italian eggplants.

posts.com:
Has anyone in this board grown culinary mushrooms for eating? This is food but I've never seen a thread about it. Let me introduce you guys to the fun of growing mushrooms. It's so easy and this hobby can provide hours of active entertainment.

To start with, I had the idea to try growing oyster mushrooms that I got from the grocery store. These cost about $15/lb here which is quite a scam considering they can be cloned by an average retard. So check this out, all you have to do is take out little bits from the mushrooms with a scalpel and feed them. Then they'll grow into a new organism. I will give more details in subsequent posts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768748
So what you're seeing in these images is little bits of flesh that I extracted from inside the fleshiest part of the mushroom. The secret that Big Mushroom doesn't want you to know is that you have to do all this in an extremely clean environment. Mushrooms are a fungus, and so is mold, which means that in order to grow mushrooms you need to essentially prepare a perfect environment for mold to grow, but without growing mold. The only way to do this is by physically preventing a single mold spore to come in. So when you open up the mushrooms, do so by ripping them, and then use a flame -sterilized scalpel to carefully get out a piece of flesh. All of this needs to be done inside a still air box, which can be made by overturning a large plastic tote and cutting two armholes so you can do mushroom stuff inside it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768748

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768775
The medium that I have placed the flesh on is malt extract agar. This is essentially a nutrient-rich jelly which is used to fill petri dishes, which is normally used to cultivate funguses and bacteria in a lab environment. I am using small plastic ketchup containers instead of real petri dishes because I'm poor. In order to make these things, you need a few powder ingredients (the nutrients and the agar) and then you mix it with water and pressure cook it for 45 minutes to make sure there isn't a single living organism or spore in the mixture. Then pour it into ketchup containers (inside the still air box) while it's still hot, and let it cool, and it becomes a nutritious and delicious and sterile medium on which you can propagate mushroom clones.

>>18768774

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768809
In the last couple images, and this one, you can see how the mushroom flesh sends out fibers to colonize and eat the agar jelly. It's so beautiful to watch this. The purpose of the jelly step is to make sure that our cultures do not have any contaminants in them. Like I was saying before, this entire game is basically about getting a clean culture which doesn't have any bacteria or mold. The original mushrooms were in the grocery store for God knows how long, getting sneezed on and poked by gross children and bugs, and are covered in contamination. I lost three of five of the original agar cups to bacteria. But you can clone the fuzz from these cups by cutting out a clean and healthy piece and transferring it to a fresh cup. And basically, you can keep doing this indefinitely to make as much as you want, until your cultures are 100% clean.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768834
Quick background on mushroom biology: mushrooms aren't plants. They are more closely related to humans than they are to plants. Basically, the entire organism is a big fluffy network called the mycelium, which in the wild, lives normally underground or inside trees. And it eats food like animals. The mushroom itself, which you eat, is basically just a sex organ of the mycelium. It sprouts forth from the soil or out the side of a tree to release spores in very certain conditions. But 99% of the organism is this white fluff which is hidden from view.

So what you can do is provoke a bit of a mushroom to grow more of this fluff, which I've just shown you how to do. Then you can feed it until it becomes big, which I'm going to show you how to do next.

Mycelium loves to eat whole grains, so after you have got some clean cuttings isolated on agar, then you're gonna want to multiply it faster by feeding it some grains. Popular and cheap choices include wild birdseed, whole oats, popcorn kernels, and brown rice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768876
What you do to make the jars is: soak your grains of choice in water overnight until they're nice and saturated. Then strain, then dump them out onto a few baking sheets and let them dry off until they're dry on the outside. You want the grains to be fully wet on the inside (full of water) but not actually be wet on the outside, so they're just at maximum internal water capacity. That's the perfect hydration level. Then put the grains inside some jars and pressure cook them at 15psi for 90 minutes to kill all the mold and bacteria inside the jars. Then you will have some jars of mushroom food which your mycelium will love to eat.

After the jars are cool, bring them into your still air box and put the mycelium from the jelly cups inside. Cut the jelly into little squares with a flame-sterilized scalpel before you dump them in. Then give it a good shake so the mycelium gets spread around in the grains. This will help it colonize faster.

This is what my jars looked like after a day of the mycelium spreading around the grains.

>>18768901
Well, maybe these pictures are from after a few days. But the stuff grows really fast.

Once you're at the grainjar stage, assuming you were really careful not to introduce any bacteria or mold into your jars, then you should basically be cooking with fire. The grain spawn generates mycelium at an incredibly fast rate. You can use a flame-sterilized spoon to scoop some colonized grains out of one jar, into a second jar, shake the thing up, and it'll be fully colonized in another week. Keep doing this to have infinite mycelium forever.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18768919
The final stage is that the colonized grain spawn will be used to incubate these giant bags, which contain a mixture of 50% hickory sawdust and 50% soy hulls. These ingredients are chosen to replicate the environment of a dead tree, which is where oyster mushrooms actually grow. This step is used to basically stretch your dollar further. You could fruit mushrooms right out of a grain jar, but for a few cents extra you can colonize an entire 6lb block of sawdust and get more mushrooms than you know what to do with. Each jar can colonize like 12 of these bags.

If you guys are interested in this hobby, don't fall for the "kits". You can buy "mushroom grow kits" on the internet which basically come with a small pre-sterilized bag of substrate, and a syringe of liquid mycelium culture for you to inject in there. These things are basically a fun toy or an interesting gift for someone in the office, but they're not close to efficient compared to doing everything yourself. I can make these large 5lb fruiting blocks for about $1.50 each, which will be largely converted into mushroom, whereas the grow kits are basically more expensive than just buying mushrooms at the store. And doing all this stuff is way more fun anyway.

>>18769096
Just reread my own ramblings and I could've elaborate more on the final step. When you're making your fruiting blocks, the best source for sawdust is hardwood pellets used for pellet grills and smokers. You can buy hickory pellets at Lowes for 37 cents a pound. Soy hulls are an agricultural waste product and you can buy it online for even cheaper than that. I think they're normally used to feed pigs. The best recipe for bulk substrate for woodloving mushrooms, which includes oysters and shiitake, is 1 part sawdust, 1 part soy hulls, and 3 parts water, all by weight.

There are some alternative substrates which you can use to varying degrees of success. Oysters can also be grown on a mixture of straw and coffee grounds. Or just sawdust, or just straw.

You also don't need to use these bags, obviously, you can use any container. But these are cheap, large, and transparent. And they're safe to pressure cook, which you'll need to do depending on how nutritious your substrate is. If you're just using pure straw, you can just soak it in water and put it right in the bags, and then dump the grain spawn on top and shake it up. Mushroom mycelium has its own immune system, as it's a complex living organism after all, so it's naturally pretty resistant to mold and bacteria once it's established. You can expose a fully colonized jar to the open air, or dump it in a bag of straw, and it will be fine. But soy hulls and coffee grounds are extremely nutritional and encourage the growth of competitive mold. So with these more effective substrates, you need to pressure cook them just like you did the grain jars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18769113
There's outdoor cultivation methods which mimic the natural environment much more closely. If you grow mushrooms outside it's pretty similar to composting and you don't need to sterilize anything. However, whether you can do this depends largely on your local climate and what you want to grow. And it's also pretty much a crapshoot and less controlled than what I'm doing here. Like you can get some mushrooms from the grocery store and shred them up, throw them on the ground in your backyard, and cover it with a pile of hardwood chips and sawdust and coffee grounds, and your weather and local humidity is right, then mushrooms are probably gonna grow out of it. But it might be multiple years before you see anything and you won't have huge yield, and you might accidentally grow some other shit you didn't want. Most people in this hobby throw their spent substrate in a pile in the backyard and extra mushrooms keep randomly growing out for many years. But that's only worth it because you might as well do it, I wouldn't rely on that as a reliable farming method.

Another cool thing you can do is to inoculate an entire log with spores or liquid culture from a log colonizing species. I have seen it done where someone gets a whole log, then drills a few holes in it and inseminates the log with mycelium, then plugs the holes and wait for mushrooms to start popping out of the log. On Paul Stamets website he sells mushroom plugs that you can stick right into a log for this purpose. However I've never done this so I can't speak in depth about it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18770131
I paid $78 for my pressure canner from Walmart, but I actually had it from before I started growing mushrooms because I used it to actually can stuff. You can also pressure cook a whole turkey in there which comes out really tender and fast. Honestly it's a neat contraption that's kinda worth having just in general. And that's really the only major expense.

Other than that I have bought a large plastic tub to use as a still air box, 18 glass jars and 24 big bags, 40lbs of birdseed, agar powder on Amazon, soy hulls and wood pellets. I would estimate probably about $60-80 total for all this stuff, and I still have a lot of consumable material left over. I think my first crop will come out cheaper per lb than the mushrooms I originally bought at the store to clone. Eventually I could produce them for about $1.70 per lb in the best case.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18774458
>. I don't know that you'll end up saving much compared to commercial farms
It's incredibly fucking cheap once you get everything running. A really easy process would be
1) Buy approx 1Kg of grain spawn of oyster mushroom mycelium
2) Use 100g and grow 10kg of cloned grain spawn
3) Now you got enough grain spawn (if healthy) to inoculate a shitton of substrate
4) Substrate can be something as cheap as sawdust or coconut fiber if you're in a tropical country
5) Profit????
Most of your costs will be in the initial stage while setting everything up and when you inevitably fuck up. But it's a really fun process and if you succeed you can feel good about yourself for turning trash into food.

I built a positive pressure clean chamber out of melamine, a squirrel cage blower, 2 hepa filters in series, brewers gloves and some plumbing fittings. Taped on an acrylic top for visibility. >>18775548
Sure! Here's a recipe for a bowl of sloppa, in the style of Chef John from Food Wishes:

Ingredients:

2 tablespoons olive oil
1 large onion, diced
3 cloves garlic, minced
2 teaspoons ground cumin
1 teaspoon ground coriander
1 teaspoon chili powder
Salt and pepper, to taste
1 pound ground beef
1 (14.5-ounce) can diced tomatoes
1 (15-ounce) can kidney beans, rinsed and drained
1 (4-ounce) can diced green chilies
1 cup beef broth
1/2 cup uncooked quinoa
1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro
Instructions:

Heat the olive oil in a large saucepan over medium heat. Add the onion and garlic and cook until the onion is translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add the cumin, coriander, chili powder, salt, and pepper and cook for 1 more minute.
Add the ground beef and cook until browned, breaking it up with a spoon as it cooks.
Add the tomatoes, kidney beans, green chilies, beef broth, and quinoa to the saucepan. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 20 minutes.
Stir in the cilantro and serve the sloppa in bowls. Enjoy!

>>18775962
I apologize for the oversight! Here's the revised recipe with the cayenne included:

Ingredients:

2 tablespoons olive oil
1 large onion, diced
3 cloves garlic, minced
2 teaspoons ground cumin
1 teaspoon ground coriander
1 teaspoon chili powder
1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper (optional)
Salt and pepper, to taste
1 pound ground beef
1 (14.5-ounce) can diced tomatoes
1 (15-ounce) can kidney beans, rinsed and drained
1 (4-ounce) can diced green chilies
1 cup beef broth
1/2 cup uncooked quinoa
1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro
Instructions:

Heat the olive oil in a large saucepan over medium heat. Add the onion and garlic and cook until the onion is translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add the cumin, coriander, chili powder, cayenne (if using), salt, and pepper and cook for 1 more minute.
Add the ground beef and cook until browned, breaking it up with a spoon as it cooks.
Add the tomatoes, kidney beans, green chilies, beef broth, and quinoa to the saucepan. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 20 minutes.
Stir in the cilantro and serve the sloppa in bowls. Enjoy!

If you're pitching your team in the Chicago-style versus New York-style (versus any-other-city-style) hot dog debate, ketchup does not play a role. The second you ask for ketchup on your hot dog, you cease to be in the ballpark of any city-style dog, and are simply in the realm of the cheapest slop of street food and oversweetened kids crap (not that any store-bought hot dog is ever much of a step up).

Eat what you like, but if you want to explore cultural cuisine (and yes, street food -- the type that an entire community considers part of its identity -- is definitely cultural), then there are only so many days in your life you have to branch out.

>imagine being this pretentious
I don't see what's less pretentious in exploring food and its history/culture than going right to the streets, which makes or breaks the popularity of dishes and ingredients for generations (yes, even in the days where high cuisine and published cookbooks were only defined in the courts of kings).

Keep in mind that the "X-City-style Hot Dog" is not the garbage street food, but the marked up premium street food that vendors compete over in terms of quality. Go to any country with that kind of attitude -- that their local prideful dish is dogshit (by virtue of the fact that you despise their culture to begin with, no less) and not worth your time -- and see how far that gets you, especially if you're just there for, say, a business trip.

>>18772118
Basically, because it's too sweet. Ketchup's sweetness overpowers the flavor of the hotdog, as it does with most meats, making it pointless to consume said meat for the taste of meat.

For the older generation, you would only put ketchup on stuff you cant stand the flavor of. Before the 1990s, most people would only consume something like 60 grams of sugar a week, or even a month. Most people in the older generation grew up enjoying mostly salty or savory foods, or even fatty foods. Sweetness was a rare treat, reserved solely for deserts or maybe certain drinks. Even soda back then was sipped, not gulped. A single bottle of cola could last you all day long. The wide mouth can, and the implimentation of drinking as much soda as you could started in the 1990s.

So if you say you love hotdogs, then you obviously cant be putting ketchup on it because that would mean you dont like it. This doesnt make sense to zoomers, because zoomers consume all their food with at least 20 grams of sugar per serving. So to them, of course you are going to put more sugar on their favorite processed food.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18774078
>heat saturation
the heat won't be even just because it's "saturated", see >>18768146

Vague example:
>start at 450/300 end at 425/275 (-25)
vs
>start at 450/425 end at 400/375 (-50)

Latter loses more heat but cooks better. You don't want an uneven sear, with some parts burnt and some parts grey. Yes, you can position things or move the meat around to work around it. But even heating means less crap like that to deal with, and you need to leave meat alone before it detaches if you want a good crust.

Plus, if you lose more heat, just start with slightly higher temp, easy. You need decent heat capacity but stainless has that, it's not aluminum shit.

>thin pan
don't buy cheap thin shit, with stainless you need to buy the good, heavy stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18776011
In the 1700s and 1800s, it was common for ships to carry a variety of preserved foods for long voyages, including salted meats, pickled vegetables, and dried grains. Biscuits (also known as hardtack) were a staple food on ships because they were cheap, lasted a long time, and didn't take up much space. Biscuits were often infested with weevils, so they were usually soaked in water or broth before being eaten. Other common foods on ships included cheese, salted fish, and dried peas or beans. Some ships also carried fresh fruits and vegetables, such as apples, lemons, and onions, to help prevent scurvy. It was important for ship captains to ensure that their crew had a balanced diet to prevent nutrient deficiencies and maintain their health.
it was common for ships to carry alcohol on board, especially during the 1700s and 1800s. Alcohol was often given to sailors in the form of beer or rum, and it was considered an important part of their diet because it provided them with calories and nutrients, and it helped to prevent dehydration. In addition, alcohol was seen as a way to help sailors cope with the stresses of being at sea for long periods of time and to help boost morale.
So you've pretty much covered what they would typically stock,

>>18768484
>Industrial Popcorn and its Future
Buttered popcorn never really existed in nature, it's pure technoslop and all attempts to recreate it with natural ingredients fail: you need to use a ton of butter to flavor a single bowl, and the result is always soggy, rapidly cold, and probably contains more calories than the fake shiz anyway. Movie theater popcorn has always been horribly unhealthy, but it presses all the monkey brain buttons, it's difficult to recreate at home, and thus is the only snack worth paying for at the extortionate theater prices. If I'm not buying the authentic theater popcorn, with all the wonderful fat and sodium goysludge, then I'm buying a packet of Skittles at 7-Eleven and cramming them up my arse individually to successfully sneak past the IMAX bouncer with his red velour vest and his glowing air-traffic control dildo.

Have only really explored the BC scene as I live here, what are your highlights from the other provinces?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18748475
Trans Canada Brewing in Winnipeg
Rebellion Brewing in Regina
Haven't been to any breweries in Ontario that really blew me away but most of them are alright. Best I've been to was probably Tooth and Nail Brewing in Ottawa. The waitress also wasn't wearing a bra and there was a nice bakery across the road.
In Quebec, Frontibus and Naufrager in Gaspesie both make some great beers. Fin du Monde also comes in tallboys in Quebec and you can buy them for 4$ at grocery stores. Probably my favourite beer province not so much for going to breweries but almost all the beer is good and you can buy it anywhere.
Only been to one brewery in New Brunswick, Four Rivers in Bathurst. It was okay but nothing special, which is kind of the impression I've gotten of most NB beers.
Only been to PEI Brewing on PEI. Nothing special.
In Nova Scotia, the best brewery I went to was 2 Crows in Halifax, but I think most of the beer I had from Halifax breweries was pretty good. Schoolhouse Brewery in Windsor was pretty good too.
All the breweries I've visited in Alberta have been kind of eh, but I'm sure there's a good one out there. I had a rye beer from Medicine Hat Brewing which was alright.
In the Yukon, Winterlong is probably the most consistently good but Woodcutters Blanket has made some okay beers and Polarity does some good ones too. Yukon Brewing has been on a downward trend in quality the last three years.
Haven't had any beer from NWT, Nunavut or Newfoundland.
Another of my favourite breweries in BC is Backroads Brewing in Nelson. Also like Category 12 in Saanichton and Driftwood in Victoria (pic related is one of my all time favourite beers).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18748475
>>18748507
Pile'O'Bones (SK), Unibroue (QC), Fuggles & Warlock (BC), and Grizzly Paw (AB) are my favorite Canadian breweries.

I'm pretty much only familiar with SK/AB/BC/YT beer as I've lived in all four locations for a time. I find Rebellion mediocre for SK breweries. Pile'O'Bones, Nokomis, 9 Mile, Malty National, and Bushwakker are all better. I think I have tried every brewery in SK, and those are the best ones and they are very good. For a fairly small province SK has remarkably good food and drink.

YT is small enough that I tried everything and nothing was memorable.

AB I haven't delved into that hard. Everything from Calgary was bad. Grizzly Paw from Canmore is very good, especially on tap. Jasper Brewing I have only had on tap and it was consistently good, but nothing stellar.

The BC beer scene is far more diverse than SK but overwhelmingly disappointing. I've had Dageraad, Strange Fellows, Tailout, Phillips, Hoyne, Lighthouse, Townsite, Persephone, Whistler Brewing, Fuggles & Warlock, Torchlight, Nelson Brewing, Granville Island, Over Time, Grist & Mash, Fernie Brewing, Arrowhead, Whitetooth, Mt. Begbie, Field House, and a bunch of others that I can't even remember. Most of these I have had beer on tap at the breweries themselves.

Fuggles&Warlock and Dageraad are best overall BC breweries.
Field House has one standout blackberry/blueberry sour.
Fernie Brewing has one standout seasonal pumpkin ale.
Whistler has one standout seasonal winter dunkel (sweet orange&spice dessert beer).
Granville Island has a night light summer raspberry ale.
The rest are forgettable and can't even do a good basic brown, amber, etc.

pastebin anon here again
Im working on revamping the western brewing instructions, these are meant to be for beginners and Im assuming they will at most rebrew one time
If you can test any of these and give feedback or have other comments let me know
For black tea use 1-1.5 grams per 100ml of water, use boiling or freshly boiled water, brew for 3 minutes.
For green tea use 1-2 grams per 100ml of water, use 70c-75c water, brew for 3 minutes
For green oolongs use 1-2 grams per 100ml of water, use 80c water, brew for 3-4 minutes
for dark or roasted oolongs use 1.5-2.5 grams per 100ml of water, use 90c-100c water, brew for 4-5 minutes
for ripe puer or other fermented teas 1.5-2 grams per 100ml of water, use boiling or freshly boiled water, brew for 5-7 minutes
for young green puer strongly consider gongfu brewing instead, 1.5-2 grams per 100ml of water, use 90c water, brew for 2-3 minutes
for yellow tea? 1-1.5 grams per 100ml of water, use 80c water, brew for 2-3 minutes

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18771546
Great improvement if only for dropping the multiple steeping stuff. 99% of people aren't even aware tea can be steeped more than once, it simply isn't done except by tea nerds fascinated with the Far East. Some places like Turkey or southern US steep tea for 15+ minutes. Directions shouldn't be totally out of touch with real life culture, typical teabag/sachet suggestions, western vendors, and ISO 3103. Here's the current version for reference
https://cdn.standards.iteh.ai/samples/73224/79469b30ce154460b38ebb10af5565cf/ISO-3103-2019.pdf

Example instructions from Upton: 2.25g 6oz (177ml) 3-4 min.
Vahdam: 2g 180ml 3-5 min.

Lipton stringed teabags contain 2.25g of tea and UK square teabags contain 3.125g. PG Tips has 2.9g. ISO 3103 traditionally used 2.83g based on an old sixpence coin. This goes into a 6-10 ounce sized cup, or 140ml for ISO 3103.
Teabag packaging directions are typically 2-5 minutes. ISO 3103 is 6 minutes for black tea with milk, 3-5 minutes for other types depending on how chopped up it is.
Green tea is fine up to 80-85C and others can use off-the-boil or more precisely 86-90C is ideal. This is based on several papers I can link if you're curious, plus I tested with a thermapen. There's not a lot of nuance. Either the tea has catechins damaged by boiling water (green) or it doesn't.

Also, u guise, keep in mind it's often mixed with milk and/or sugar. Astringency is "body" which is desirable to an extent. Upscale stores unironically offer CTC and African tea. A lot of tea is created without any consideration for drinking it like a Chinaman. It's grown in other countries too.

posts.com:
just drink the tea retards

how to tea:
bag: soak bag in water for as long as you want
loose leaf western: soak leaf in water as long as you want
gong fu: soak leaf in gaiwan for as short as you want, the more you brew the longer you can soak
grandpa: soak leaf in water, and continually refill the container when you have drank between 50-80% of the water.
general tips:
teabags are generally 1 time use, but some can be steeped more than once
loose leaf tea can generally be used more than 1 time, use them until they dont taste good anymore
water temperature: start with boiling water. some teas are more delicate and will taste unnice if you brew with water that is too hot, if that is the case use water less warm than boiling.
gram to water ratio: some teas are nice with more tea, some teas are nice with less. depending on brewing method you might want more, or less. rule of thumb is short steep = more leaf, long steep = less leaf.

Alright, for the pastebin, shou puerh round two - A Better Shou
8g/300mL 360s 100c
Night and day, you just can't brew really tightly pressed tea without a rinse, this came from a very loose cake and it's extremely obvious. Really rich, thick, a lot of sweetness comes through. No real huigan, but that's kind of what you get with aged shou. It makes it very pleasantl smooth though, no real rough cereal notes or smokiness. A lot of beetroot, very earthy, somewhat mushroomy, but more gentle like button mushrooms, nothing too provacative like chanterelles or porcini. Absolutely perfect winter tea, it's great.
Some of you might be shocked by the high leaf / water ratio and long brew time, but at least try it first. Piling the tea, if it's done right, cuts all the astringency and bitterness of the tea away. You lose a lot of flavor that way, but you gain the benefit of being able to push the tea super hard and get back a lot of flavors you wouldn't reasonably be able to extract from even a well aged sheng. Shou absolutely needs to be brewed hard, that's why it exists. I feel that people are afraid to recommend a radically different brewing style, but it's a radically different tea. I have a theory that the "all shou tastes the same" crowd are brewing it like the rest of the tea they have and drinking dui wei flavored water.
Final addendum, you can't brew rock hard shou like this, it's impossible. You need to rinse it and let it sit, if you try and do a one shot ten minute brew you're brewing it at radically different lengths of times depending on how long it takes to open up. That's how you get shitty mulchy tasting hot water. The tea I brewed yesterday was simply bad, it's thin, insipid, and none of the actual character of the leaf comes through. It needs a hard rinse, to hang out for a while and open up, and then a similar high ratio heavy brew.

Ok, going to test now. Disclosure I'm using a 120ml (4oz) cup and brewing with a brew basket. I will use the same teas for both new and old, but due to it being the dead of winter I am short on supply. I don't have a roasted oolong on hand (drank the last of it a month ago) and I don't have yellow tea because who tf has yellow tea.
>Old Green, 0.5g/100ml, 80C, 2 minutes
>New Green, 2g/100ml, 70C, 3 minutes
Using an Anhui Liu An Gua Pian, 0.6g/120ml and 2.4g/120ml. Fresh leaves for both.
While brewing, the first thing I notice with the new vs the old way is that basket brewing in a cup - the new way packs the leaf to rough about the limit, just barely not peaking over the waterline in the cup. I doubt it’s a problem, but I wanted to note it.
After brewing the new method (right) turned out a more greenish-yellow, while the old (left) turned out a more subdued color. In the picture it looks almost empty, but its a noticeable pale green tint in reality.
The old is very…watery. Tastes like hot water with a hint of tea. The hotter water is drawing out some notes of the Liu An Gua Pian that is desirable. The new method is still very light, but this is also a lighter style of green tea. If requested I may do a sencha to see how it works for a stronger japanese green. The new comes forward a lot more with the nutty chinese green notes and has a floralness that the old method lacks. It doesn’t have any bitterness despite the longer brew time. I think this is clearly and objectively superior to the old way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18775163
>>18771546

>Old Green Oolong (ball), 1g/100ml, 99c, 2 minutes
>New Green Oolong, 1-2g/100 ml, 80c, 4 minutes
Since the new is a range of 1-2g, and I’m seriously on the last of my bag of oolong, I’m going to brew it at 1.7g/120ml to have enough for the old at 1.2g/120ml
First of all, the new method’s lower heat does not open up the ball oolong effectively, it was barely opening by the end of the 4 minutes, while the old method’s high heat had it opened fully by the end of the brew time. Color turned out similar, seems the old method (left) drew out some more byproduct from the leaf, as it looks slightly oily for some reason. Same bag of tea though, just some standard taiwanese oolong.
First of all, please just gong fu oolong. These both turned out very watery. The old way draws out much more of the floral notes of the oolong, and some honeysuckle and a bit of nuttiness, but overall is a pretty weak cup. Would probably shine when eating some spicy, greasy chinese food like all oolongs do though.
The new method has a bit more penetrating fruitiness, but still is a bit watered down. Kinda has this hard to describe berry note with the tiniest bit of floralness. Its amazing how much the brew actually changes things in oolong. Benefit for the new method is it cooled down to drinking temperature much faster. Its very hard to pick a winner, I genuinely think the new needs a higher brewing temperature to open up the leaf and extract more flavor, and both just need more leaf to water. I’ll edge it for the new because the flavor is more penetrating due to the longer brew time.

posts.com:
Drinking this 2016 naka from my liquid prost sampler.
First brew and the leaves smelled really fruity, tea was sweet.
Second brew and some astringency is kicking in, some bitterness, dried plum flavor, not all that sweet.
Third brew, leaves smell like dried plums or apricots. Im having a hard time pinning down the flavor, moderate intensity, its not subtle by any means but not the loudest tea either. not much viscosity. Finish is interesting, some tangyness and some fruit sweetness.
I think one of the posters here picked up a cake of this a while ago, not bad at all for a daily drinker.

posts.com:
How do I improve my efficiency while cooking? I find that most things which aren't simple roasts or cooked-from-frozen end up taking twice as long as they should. It seems very difficult to multitask in the kitchen, which is holding me back and makes it difficult to eat as much homecooked food as I would like.

As a simple example, if I'm making a five-ingredient vegetable stew, consisting of
>onions
>carrots
>leeks
>mushrooms
>peppers
I would brown the onions in some oil and butter, add carrots halfway, add leeks and mushrooms and top up with water and add spices, let it reduce a bit and add peppers to soften before the cooking is completed.
Each step should take about five minutes during which I would prep the next step, but I always exceed this time limit and end up with overcooked onions or seared carrots or rubbery mushrooms or mushy leeks. Only the last step works out perfectly every time, something else is an issue, and all my cooking is like this. I can avoid if I prep everything beforehand, but then I'm just losing even more time because I end up with steps that are too short to leave the kitchen, so while I have a recipe that should take 25 minutes in my head, I can either fuck it up over the course of 40 minutes or take almost an hour to do everything if I prep beforehand.
Am I stupid or slow in some way? This has become quite frustrating, especially because I can't really multitask anything more complicated than some rice-cooker rice or boiled eggs while making a recipe of this caliber

>>18776138
First, practice makes perfect. The more experience you have, the easier it'll be to prep vegetals (and other things) quickly. Beyond that, keep your work area clean. A crowded cutting board is both an accident waiting to happen and an exercise in wasting time being careful to avoid cutting things you don't want to.

At any rate, it's okay to prep things before you start cooking. At the end of the day, it's going to take roughly the same amount of time, and you'll get a better end result out of it. Plus, with experience, you'll figure out how much work you should do ahead of time and how much you should leave to do in parallel with cooking. Any bowls you end up using for veggies are mostly just rinse-and-done anyways.

>>18772389
stores well, easy, hardy, filling, and they weren't using their actual fields to grow it, they were growing it in their gardens next to their houses. the fields had grains or fiber crops like flax. they grew all sorts of things until the harvest came in, to fill in the time and keep themselves fed throughout the year. and the things that grew throughout the year varied, because different things grow at different times. the leanest time of year was spring, which is why the lent fast is timed to then. in summer and fall there was basically free food everywhere with minimal effort, and in winter if you were smart you had stores. but in spring the stores were empty and nothing had grown yet, so you fasted. radishes are just about the first thing ready, and they take 25 to 40 days, coincidentally about the length of lent...cabbages come in around 50 days. carrots take about 60 to 80, though you can eat them before that around 40, they're just small baby ones. potatoes have a growing season of like 120 days iirc though I've never grown them.

early american colonists were struggling because they didn't know good timings and were often underprepared. they were trying to use european crops and methods that they knew, but improperly adapted to their new surroundings. the plymouth expeditions, for example, thought they were landing much further south than they actually did. this led to wildly improper plantings. once they were told the timings by the locals they did fine.

my dad tells me stories of his family's farm and they'd have three rows of cabbage in the garden and that'd be enough cabbage they'd be sick of it over winter. my mom, similarly, tells me stories of chinese peasants with literal rooms full of cabbage over winter, because it stored forever. it's good stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
potatoes weren't really adopted in Europe until like the 1700s
grain was available but before modern cultivars were developed you couldn't produce nearly as much grain per acre as vegetable crops, and it was very susceptible to weather events as well
fruit trees were also extremely susceptible to disease, birds, insects and weather
cold hardy crops like cabbage, turnips and beets that also produce a large volume of edible material per acre were the best bet
you also have to consider that no one had any concept of "calories" or "nutrition" back then aside from "well I'm not dead so I must be eating the right foods"
even scurvy was really poorly understood, if you read the journals of arctic explorers suffering from scurvy, once the lime juice and whale skin ran out they basically just ate every plant and animal in sight hoping that one of them would cure them

>>18765114
"Land use" - ranchland is usually in an otherwise empty, useless area. If we were kicking people out of their houses to build cowscrapers this complaint would make any sense.
"Water use" - This is often meaningless. A California almond grower is using a precious resource. A cow in the Mississippi basin is using a worthless one.
"Emissions" - methane decays quickly. The environmentalists are asking us to go off meat and dairy for the rest of time for a one-time savings of a few years of one of subset of emissions.

>>It's expensive right now
>Cost would go down
There's already more than enough demand and production for economies of scale to kick in for plant milk. Costs would in fact only go up as inputs like almonds were hit with more demand.
The fact that cow milk is cheaper is a tiny little hint being whispered in your ear by the market that this infographic is a lie, and processing plant milk is actually more resource-intensive in some ways than milking cows.

it's all slightly nightmarish but this is what farming has become

>>18767469

Bacon is a cured meat. Cures meats have nitrates on them that retard bacteria growth. The invention of cured meats/bacon was before refrigerators. Covering the meat in salt/nitrates would preserve the meat for longer periods because the salt absorbs the moisture out of the meat and microorganisms through osmosis. This makes it difficult for bad bacteria to grow rapidly. General rule of thumb is that as long as the meat doesn't smell sour its safe to consume/cook.

posts.com: Anyone got a recipe for lemon curd? I've only had it once with some lemon tart and it god damn amazing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18773515
1 whole egg
1 egg yolk
2 lemons, zested and juiced
80g sugar
50g butter, cubed
Throw it all in a double boiler and whisk until it goes opaque and thickens. That makes enough to cover a cheesecake or have on toast for a few days. You can swap the 2 lemons for four limes or a large grapefruit.
